newsitem.title: USA: US Midwest power rises on cooler weather forecast.
newsitem.headline: US Midwest power rises on cooler weather forecast.

text.p: Spot bulk electricity prices in the midwestern U.S. for Monday delivery were mostly higher Friday, led by forecasts calling for cooler weather next week.

Temperatures throughout the Midwest are forecast to remain well above-normal through Saturday, but the arrival of a cool front late Saturday will push temperatures down to near-normal levels by early next week.
Contributing to the rise in prices, traders said, was the anticipated increase in industrial load following the holiday.

In the Mid-Continent Area Power Pool (MAPP), peak, non-firm power prices for Monday delivery were discussed mostly in the $16.00-$17.50 per megawatt hour (MWh) area, as compared with Thursday's trading range of $15.00-16.50.
Off-peak non-firm MAPP power for Monday was also higher in the $11.00-12.00.

In the Mid-American Interpool Network (MAIN), peak, non-firm power prices for Monday climbed into the $19.00-21.50 range, up from Thursday's trading range of $16.00-17.00 for Friday and from the $17.50-18.00 area for next week delivery.
MAIN off peak power for Monday was assessed at $11.00-12.00, but no deals were confirmed done.

Peak, non-firm electricity prices in the East Central Area Reliability Coordination Agreement (ECAR) for Monday were talked in the $14.00-20.00 range, with most deals reported done in the $16.00-17.00 area.
These prices compare with the $13.25-15.00 range on Thursday.
ECAR electricity prices for off-peak, non-firm delivery were quoted at $11.00-$12.00.
January ECAR prices were talked around $23.00, while February ECAR was assessed in the $23.00-24.00 range.

In the Southwest Power Pool (SPP), where temperatures are expected to dip to about five to 20 degrees above-normal this weekend, peak, non-firm power prices for Monday delivery rebounded into the $15.00-16.00 range, up from Thursday's $9.00-10.00 trading range.
Off-peak prices throughout SPP for Monday delivery were notionally assessed at $11.00-12.00.
Temperatures in the SPP region are expected to drop to normal levels Sunday and Monday.
January peak prices in SPP were still in the $20.00-22.00 area, while the July/August market was talked in the $27.75-28.50 range.
Separately, Detroit Edison's 1,116 megawatt (MW) Fermi 2 nuclear unit in Michigan is expected to return to the electricity grid "in the next couple of days."

Also, American Electric Power Co's 1,090 MW Cook 2 nuclear unit in Michigan, which has been operating at 55 percent power, will likely begin ramping up later today, with full power expected on Sunday.
Omaha Public Power District's 478 MW Fort Calhoun nuclear unit returned to full power after shutting on December 31.

Furthermore, Commonwealth Edison's 794 MW Dresden 2 unit is expected to begin ramping up this weekend from its 40 percent power level, while Dresden 3, with the same generating capacity, is still slated to restart January 13.
ComEd's 1,105 MW Byron 2 is holding at 75 percent power after dipping to about half power late Thursday. The company said the unit will likely increase power later Friday or early Saturday.
Also, the 1,040 MW Zion 2 unit, is expected to be on-line early next week, ComEd said.
All of these ComEd units are in Illinois.
Natural gas prices in the Midwest were also higher in the $2.31-2.36 per million British thermal units (mmBtu) range, while south Texas values were up about four cents to the mid-$2.30s per mmBtu.
((--H McCulloch, New York Power Desk +212-859-1628))
